Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Impact of Early Algebra on Students' Algebra-Readiness

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Impact of Early Algebra on Students' Algebra-Readiness is a collaborative project at the University of Wisconsin and TERC, Inc. They are implementing and studying a research-based curriculum that was designed to help children in grades 3-5 prepare for learning algebra at the middle school level. Researchers are investigating the impact of a long-term, comprehensive early algebra experience on students as they proceed from third grade to sixth grade. Researchers are working to build a learning progression that describes how algebraic concepts develop and mature from early grades through high school. This study helps to build our knowledge about the piece of the progression that is just prior to entering middle school where many students begin formal instruction in algebra.

Building on previous research about early algebra learning, researchers will teach a curriculum that was carefully designed to reflect what we know about learning algebraic concepts. Previous research has shown that young children from very diverse backgrounds have the ability to construct algebraic ideas such as equality, representation, generalization, and functions. Researchers are collecting data about students' algebraic knowledge as well as arithmetical knowledge.

We know that the majority of students in the United States struggle with learning formal algebra. By studying the implementation of the research-based curriculum for an extended period of time, researcher's are learning about how algebraic ideas are connected and whether or not early instruction on algebraic ideas will help students learn more formal ideas in middle school.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Teaching and learning algebra is a critical goal in school mathematics. To prepare students for college and give them choices in STEM-related careers, it is now widely accepted that algebra education should begin informally in the elementary grades. However, innovative, research-based models of algebra education in elementary grades, as well as an understanding of how such models impact students’ understanding of core algebraic concepts and practices and their algebra readiness in middle grades, are needed in order to fully implement this perspective.

This project examined the impact of a Grades 3–5 early algebra intervention on children’s understanding of core algebraic concepts and practices, such as generalizing and justifying mathematical relationships, representing such relationships in words, variables, tables and graphs, and reasoning with generalized claims. In particular, a quasi-experimental design was used to compare the algebraic thinking of students (treatment group) who received the early algebra intervention across Grades 3–5 to students (control group) in more traditional, arithmetic-focused classrooms. The core finding of this project was that, although there were no significant differences in treatment and control students’ performance on an assessment of algebraic concepts and practices at Grade 3 pre-test, treatment students significantly outperformed control students at each of Grades 3 – 5 post-tests. Not only did treatment students significantly outperform control students in terms of their overall correctness on the assessments, treatment students also used more sophisticated algebraic solution strategies. Other findings include that classrooms where instruction promotes students’ activity of generalizing can serve to increase this type of core algebraic activity, thus highlighting the need to attend to strong teacher preparation for fostering algebraic thinking in elementary grades. Additional findings include that students’ understanding of core concepts such as mathematical equivalence (i.e., whether they interpret the equal sign as a relational or operational symbol) significantly predicts their ability to represent functional relationships using variable notation. Such results suggest that when students experience a broad, sustained approach to early algebra instruction, they are better positioned for success in algebra in middle grades.

In summary, this project addresses a critical national need by contributing evidence regarding children’s capacity for algebraic thinking, along with a field-tested model and tools for effective early algebra education.  In particular, the early algebra intervention studied here offers instructional resources that Grades 3 – 5 teachers can use to implement early algebra instruction in their everyday classroom practice. In this sense, this project helps to provide practical solutions that can contribute to the development of a globally competitive algebra education.
